publication.title: Model-based runtime analysis of distributed reactive systems
publication.keyword: Automatic Generation;Distributed System;Everyday Life;Linear Time;Reactive System;Runtime Analysis;Safety Properties;
publication.abstract: Reactive distributed systems have pervaded everyday life and objects, but often lack measures to ensure adequate be- haviour in the presence of unforeseen events or even errors at runtime. As interactions and dependencies within dis- tributed systems increase, the problem of detecting failures which depend on the exact situation and environment condi- tions they occur in grows. As a result,

publication.title: Tools for Traceable Security Verification
publication.keyword: Data Security;Dependable Systems;Design Model;Internet Security;Protocol Implementation;Security Analysis;Security Requirements;Software Evolution;Tool Support;
publication.abstract: Dependable systems evolution has been identified by the UK Computing Research Committee (UKCRC) as one of the current grand challenges for computer science. We present work towards addressing this challenge which focusses on one facet of dependability, namely data security: We give an overview on an approach for model- based security verification which provides a traceability link to the implementation.

publication.title: Simplifying Diagnosis Using LSAT: A Propositional Approach to Reasoning from First Principles
publication.keyword: First Principle;Formal Specification;Model Based Diagnosis;Model Based Reasoning;Propositional Logic;Sat Solver;Satisfiability;
publication.abstract: In face of the unwieldiness of non-monotonic logic solving engines, or meta interpreters usually authored in Prolog/CLP as they are commonly used for model-based reasoning and diagnosis, this paper proposes a simple, but eective improvement for performing the complex diagnostic task. The chosen approach is twofold: firstly, the problem of contradicting first order system descriptions with a set of observations

publication.title: Tool-support for the analysis of hybrid systems and models
publication.jconf: Design, Automation, and Test in Europe
publication.keyword: Constraint Solving;Control System;Domain Specificity;Expert Knowledge;Hybrid System;Industrial Case Study;System Modeling;Tool Support;Multi Domain;
publication.abstract: This paper introduces a method and tool-support for the automatic analysis and verification of hybrid and embed- ded control systems, whose continuous dynamics are often modelled using MATLAB/Simulink. The method is based upon converting system models into the uniform input lan- guage of our efficient multi-domain constraint solving li- brary, ABSOLVER, which is then used for subsequent anal- ysis. Basically,

publication.title: LTL Goal Specifications Revisited
publication.keyword: Linear Temporal Logic;Satisfiability;
publication.abstract: The language of linear temporal logic (LTL) has been proposed as a formalism for specifying temporally extended goals and search control constraints in planning. However, the semantics of LTL is defined wrt. infinite state sequences, while a finite plan generates only a finite trace. This necessitates the use of a finite trace semantics for LTL. A common approach is to

publication.title: Loose synchronization of event-triggered networks for distribution of synchronous programs
publication.keyword: Discrete Time;Distributed Application;Embedded Software;Hardware Design;Hardware Synthesis;Real Time Application;State Space;synchronous dataflow;Synchronous Language;Synchronous Programming;Real Time Control;Time Triggered Architecture;
publication.abstract: Dataflow synchronous languages have attracted considerable interest in domains such as real-time control and hardware design. The potential benefits are promising: Discrete-time semantics and deterministic concurrency reduce the state-space of parallel designs, and the engineer's intuition of uniformly progressing physical time is clearly reflected. However, for deriving implementations, use of synchronous programs is currently limited to hardware synthesis, generation of

publication.title: Compatibility and reuse in component-based systems via type and unit inference
publication.keyword: Component Reuse;component-based design;Component Based Systems;Control System;Levels of Abstraction;System Design;
publication.abstract: In many branches of industry, the component-based ap- proach to systems design is predominant, e. g., as in embed- ded control systems which are often modelled using MAT- LAB/Simulink. In order to facilitate reuse, and to raise the level of abstraction for future designs and frequently used functions, the employed tool sets offer built-in mech- anisms to create sophisticated component

publication.title: Runtime Verification Using a Temporal Description Logic
publication.keyword: Description Logic;Dynamic System;Linear Temporal Logic;Model Checking;Runtime Verification;Satisfiability;Transition Systems;
publication.abstract: Formulae of linear temporal logic (LTL) can be used to spec- ify (wanted or unwanted) properties of a dynamical system. In model checking, the system's behavior is described by a transition system, and one needs to check whether all possible traces of this transition system satisfy the formula. In runtime verication, one observes the actual sys- tem behavior, which at

publication.title: Monitoring of Real-Time Properties
publication.jconf: Foundations of Software Technology and Theoretical Computer Science
publication.keyword: Linear Temporal Logic;Natural Extension;Runtime Monitoring;Real Time;Standard Model;
publication.abstract: unchen Abstract. This paper presents a construction for runtime monitors that check real-time properties expressed in timed LTL (TLTL). Due to D'Souza's results, TLTL can be considered a natural extension of LTL towards real-time. Moreover, a typical obstacle in runtime verication is solved both for untimed and timed for- mulae, in that standard models of linear temporal logic are innite

SALT - Structured Assertion Language for Temporal Logic
publication.jconf: IEEE International Conference on Formal Engineering Methods
publication.keyword: Design Rationale;Language Development;Levels of Abstraction;Reactive System;Regular Expression;Temporal Logic;Real Time;Real Time Logic;
publication.abstract: This paper presents Salt. Salt is a general purpose speci- cation and assertion language developed for creating concise temporal specications to be used in industrial verication environments. It incor- porates ideas of existing approaches, such as specication patterns, but also provides nested scopes, exceptions, support for regular expressions and real-time. The latter is needed in particular for verication tasks to

publication.title: Security protocols, properties, and their monitoring
publication.keyword: language-based security;Open Source;Protocol Implementation;Protocol Specification;Runtime Verification;Safety Properties;Satisfiability;Security Properties;Security Protocol;Security Requirements;Temporal Logic;
publication.abstract: This paper examines the suitability and use of runtime verification as means for monitoring security protocols and their properties. In particular, we employ the runtime verification framework intro- duced in (5) to monitor complex, history-based security-properties of the SSL-protocol. We give a detailed account of the methodol- ogy, compare its formal expressiveness to prior art, and describe its application to

publication.title: A First-Order Policy Language for History-Based Transaction Monitoring
publication.jconf: International Colloquium on Theoretical Aspects of Computing
publication.keyword: Linear Temporal Logic;Model Checking;Partial Observation;Policy Language;Polynomial Time;First Order;
publication.abstract: Online trading invariably involves dealings between strangers, so it is important for one party to be able to judge objectively the trust- worthiness of the other. In such a setting, the decision to trust a user may sensibly be based on that user's past behaviour. We introduce a specication language based on linear temporal logic for expressing a policy for

publication.title: Don't care in SMT-Building flexible yet efficient abstraction/refinement solvers
publication.keyword: Case Study;Control System;Off The Shelf;Satisfiability Modulo Theories;
publication.abstract: This paper describes a method for combining "off-the-shelf " SAT and constraint solvers for building an efficient Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solver for a wide range of theories. Our method follows the abstrac- tion/refinement approach to simplify the implementation of custom SMT solvers. The expected performance penalty by not using an interweaved combination of SAT and theory solvers is reduced

publication.title: The Contribution of Free Software to Software Evolution
publication.jconf: International Workshop on Principles of Software Evolution
publication.keyword: Best Practice;Development Process;Free Software;Open Source;Open Source Development;Software Evolution;Software Systems;
publication.abstract: It is remarkable to think that even without any interest in finding suitable methods and concepts that would allow complex software systems to evolve and remain manage- able, the ever growing open source movement has silently managed to establish highly successful evolution techniques over the last two decades. These concepts represent best practices that could be applied equally to a

publication.title: A Brief Top-Down and Bottom-Up Philosophy on Software Evolution
publication.jconf: International Workshop on Principles of Software Evolution
publication.keyword: Computer Game;Development Process;Operating System;Software Development;Software Evolution;Software Systems;Bottom Up;Top Down;
publication.abstract: The decision on whether to proceed top-down or bottom- up during software development has a strong and underes- timated impact on the quality of the final product includ- ing its later evolvability. Various examples for both strate- gies taken from such different domains as operating systems and computer games provide evidence that bottom-up devel- oped systems are more suitable for

publication.title: Matching Trace Patterns with Regular Policies
publication.jconf: Language and Automata Theory and Applications
publication.keyword: Finite Automata;Linear Temporal Logic;
publication.abstract: We consider policies that are described by regular expres- sions, finite automata, or formulae of linear temporal logic (LTL). Such policies are assumed to describe situations that are problematic, and thus should be avoided. Given a trace pattern u, i.e., a sequence of ac- tion symbols and variables, were the variables stand for unknown (i.e., not observed) sequences of actions,

publication.title: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, But How Ugly Is Ugly?
publication.keyword: Temporal Logic;
publication.abstract: When monitoring a system wrt. a property defined in some temporal logic, e.g., LTL, a major concern is to settle with an adequate interpretation of observable system events; that is, models of temporal logic formulae are usually infinite streams of events, whereas at runtime only prefixes are available. This work defines a four-valued semantics for LTL over finite traces, which

publication.title: A Novel Architecture for Situation Awareness Systems
publication.authors: franz baader,peter baumgartner,anne cregan,alfredo gabaldon,krystian ji,kevin lee,david rajaratnam,rolf schwitter
publication.keyword: Automated Reasoning;Controlled Natural Language;Decision Making;Domain Specificity;Dynamic Environment;Formal Logic;Google Earth;Information Fusion;Linear Temporal Logic;Semantic Analysis;Situation Awareness;System Architecture;Theorem Prover;Data Fusion;
publication.abstract: Situation Awareness (SA) is the problem of comprehending elements of an environment within a volume of time and space. It is a crucial factor in decision-making in dynamic environments. Current SA systems support the col- lection, filtering and presentation of data from different sources very well, and typically also some form of low-level data fusion and analysis, e.g., recognizing patterns

publication.title: Monitorability of omega-regular languages
publication.keyword: Infinite Word;Regular Expression;Regular Language;Runtime Verification;Linear Time Temporal Logic;
publication.abstract: Arguably, omega-regular languages play an important role as a specification formalism in many approaches to systems monitoring via runtime verification. However, since their elements are infinite words, not every omega-regular language can sensibly be monitored at runtime when only a finite prefix of a word, modelling the observed system behaviour so far, is available.
